speaker: PUCK
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: SCENE I. Before LEONATO'S house.

speaker: PUCK
text_entry: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: comes this night to Messina.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: when I left him.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But few of any sort, and none of name.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: home full numbers. I find here that Don Peter hath

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Much deserved on his part and equally remembered by

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: promise of his age, doing, in the figure of a lamb,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: bettered expectation than you must expect of me to

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: tell you how.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: glad of it.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I have already delivered him letters, and there

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: appears much joy in him; even so much that joy could

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: not show itself modest enough without a badge of

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: bitterness.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Did he break out into tears?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: In great measure.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: truer than those that are so washed. How much

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: wars or no?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: in the army of any sort.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What is he that you ask for, niece?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: O, he's returned; and as pleasant as ever he was.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool, reading

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: him at the bird-bolt. I pray you, how many hath he

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: but he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath an

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: excellent stomach.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And a good soldier too, lady.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a lord?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed with all

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: honourable virtues.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: It is so, indeed; he is no less than a stuffed man:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: but for the stuffing,--well, we are all mortal.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: they never meet but there's a skirmish of wit

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: between them.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: conflict four of his five wits went halting off, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: now is the whole man governed with one: so that if

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: bear it for a difference between himself and his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath left,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: companion now? He hath every month a new sworn brother.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Is't possible?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: next block.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No; an he were, I would burn my study. But, I pray

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: you, who is his companion? Is there no young

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! if

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: thousand pound ere a' be cured.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: I will hold friends with you, lady.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Do, good friend.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: You will never run mad, niece.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, not till a hot January.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Don Pedro is approached.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: cost, and you encounter it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort should

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow abides

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: and happiness takes his leave.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: is your daughter.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Her mother hath many times told me so.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: what you are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: herself. Be happy, lady; for you are like an

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: honourable father.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: like him as she is.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Benedick: nobody marks you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Is it possible disdain should die while she hath

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: in her presence.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: am loved of all ladies, only you excepted: and I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: heart; for, truly, I love none.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: A dear happiness to women: they would else have

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that: I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: swear he loves me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so some

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: gentleman or other shall 'scape a predestinate

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: scratched face.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Scratching could not make it worse, an 'twere such

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a face as yours were.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: so good a continuer. But keep your way, i' God's

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: name; I have done.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You always end with a jade's trick: I know you of old.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That is the sum of all, Leonato. Signior Claudio

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the least a month; and he heartily prays some

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To DON JOHN

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Please it your grace lead on?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I noted her not; but I looked on her.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Is she not a modest young lady?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: my simple true judgment; or would you have me speak

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: praise, too brown for a fair praise and too little

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: for a great praise: only this commendation I can

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: afford her, that were she other than she is, she

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: were unhandsome; and being no other but as she is, I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: do not like her.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: truly how thou likest her.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Would you buy her, that you inquire after her?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Can the world buy such a jewel?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting Jack,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rare carpenter? Come, in what key shall a man take

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you, to go in the song?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: looked on.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: matter: there's her cousin, an she were not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: as the first of May doth the last of December. But I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Shall I never see a bachelor of three-score again?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Go to, i' faith; an thou wilt needs thrust thy neck

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sundays. Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Re-enter DON PEDRO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What secret hath held you here, that you followed

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: not to Leonato's?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: man; I would have you think so; but, on my

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance. He is

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: in love. With who? now that is your grace's part.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Mark how short his answer is;--With Hero, Leonato's

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: short daughter.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If this were so, so were it uttered.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Like the old tale, my lord: 'it is not so, nor

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: 'twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should be

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: so.'

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: should be otherwise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very well worthy.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my troth, I speak my thought.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That I love her, I feel.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That she is worthy, I know.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: That I neither feel how she should be loved nor

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at the stake.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: of beauty.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And never could maintain his part but in the force

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: of his will.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that she

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: brought me up, I likewise give her most humble

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in my

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: all women shall pardon me. Because I will not do

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: right to trust none; and the fine is, for the which

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with love than I will get again with drinking, pick

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and hang me

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: blind Cupid.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: wilt prove a notable argument.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped on

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the shoulder, and called Adam.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, as time shall try: 'In time the savage bull

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: doth bear the yoke.'

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns and set

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: them in my forehead: and let me be vilely painted,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and in such great letters as they write 'Here is

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: good horse to hire,' let them signify under my sign

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: 'Here you may see Benedick the married man.'

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be horn-mad.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I look for an earthquake too, then.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, you temporize with the hours. In the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him I will

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath made

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: great preparation.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I have almost matter enough in me for such an

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: embassage; and so I commit you--

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To the tuition of God: From my house, if I had it,--

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the guards are but slightly basted on neither: ere

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you flout old ends any further, examine your

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: conscience: and so I leave you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: My liege, your highness now may do me good.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: No child but Hero; she's his only heir.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Dost thou affect her, Claudio?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, my lord,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: When you went onward on this ended action,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That liked, but had a rougher task in hand

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Than to drive liking to the name of love:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Have left their places vacant, in their rooms

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Come thronging soft and delicate desires,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: All prompting me how fair young Hero is,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Thou wilt be like a lover presently

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And tire the hearer with a book of words.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And I will break with her and with her father,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And thou shalt have her. Was't not to this end

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: How sweetly you do minister to love,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That know love's grief by his complexion!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But lest my liking might too sudden seem,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What need the bridge much broader than the flood?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The fairest grant is the necessity.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Look, what will serve is fit: 'tis once, thou lovest,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And I will fit thee with the remedy.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I know we shall have revelling to-night:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I will assume thy part in some disguise

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And take her hearing prisoner with the force

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And strong encounter of my amorous tale:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Then after to her father will I break;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: In practise let us put it presently.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO's house.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter LEONATO and ANTONIO, meeting

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: How now, brother! Where is my cousin, your son?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: hath he provided this music?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: He is very busy about it. But, brother, I can tell

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Are they good?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: As the event stamps them: but they have a good

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: cover; they show well outward. The prince and Count

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley in mine

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: orchard, were thus much overheard by a man of mine:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: the prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge it

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: this night in a dance: and if he found her

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: accordant, he meant to take the present time by the

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: top and instantly break with you of it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: A good sharp fellow: I will send for him; and

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: question him yourself.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it appear

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: that she may be the better prepared for an answer,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: if peradventure this be true. Go you and tell her of it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Enter Attendants

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Cousins, you know what you have to do. O, I cry you

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: mercy, friend; go you with me, and I will use your

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: skill. Good cousin, have a care this busy time.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: SCENE III. The same.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Enter DON JOHN and CONRADE

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus out

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: of measure sad?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: There is no measure in the occasion that breeds;

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: therefore the sadness is without limit.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: You should hear reason.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: And when I have heard it, what blessing brings it?

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: If not a present remedy, at least a patient

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: sufferance.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayest thou art,

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: born under Saturn, goest about to apply a moral

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: medicine to a mortifying mischief. I cannot hide

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: what I am: I must be sad when I have cause and smile

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: at no man's jests, eat when I have stomach and wait

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: for no man's leisure, sleep when I am drowsy and

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: tend on no man's business, laugh when I am merry and

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: claw no man in his humour.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Yea, but you must not make the full show of this

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: till you may do it without controlment. You have of

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: late stood out against your brother, and he hath

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: impossible you should take true root but by the

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: fair weather that you make yourself: it is needful

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: that you frame the season for your own harvest.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a rose in

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: his grace, and it better fits my blood to be

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: disdained of all than to fashion a carriage to rob

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: love from any: in this, though I cannot be said to

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: but I am a plain-dealing villain. I am trusted with

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore I

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: have decreed not to sing in my cage. If I had my

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty, I would do

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: my liking: in the meantime let me be that I am and

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: seek not to alter me.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Can you make no use of your discontent?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I make all use of it, for I use it only.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Who comes here?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Enter BORACHIO

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: What news, Borachio?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: I came yonder from a great supper: the prince your

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: brother is royally entertained by Leonato: and I

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: can give you intelligence of an intended marriage.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Will it serve for any model to build mischief on?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: What is he for a fool that betroths himself to

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: unquietness?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Who? the most exquisite Claudio?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Even he.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: A proper squire! And who, and who? which way looks

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: he?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: musty room, comes me the prince and Claudio, hand

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: in hand in sad conference: I whipt me behind the

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: arras; and there heard it agreed upon that the

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: prince should woo Hero for himself, and having

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Come, come, let us thither: this may prove food to

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: my displeasure. That young start-up hath all the

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him any way, I

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: bless myself every way. You are both sure, and will assist me?

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: To the death, my lord.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Let us to the great supper: their cheer is the

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: greater that I am subdued. Would the cook were of

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: my mind! Shall we go prove what's to be done?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: We'll wait upon your lordship.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: SCENE I. A hall in LEONATO'S house.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Was not Count John here at supper?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: I saw him not.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: him but I am heart-burned an hour after.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: He were an excellent man that were made just in the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: midway between him and Benedick: the one is too

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: like an image and says nothing, and the other too

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: like my lady's eldest son, evermore tattling.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: mouth, and half Count John's melancholy in Signior

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Benedick's face,--

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: in the world, if a' could get her good-will.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: In faith, she's too curst.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen God's

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: sending that way; for it is said, 'God sends a curst

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: cow short horns;' but to a cow too curst he sends none.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Just, if he send me no husband; for the which

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: evening. Lord, I could not endure a husband with a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: What should I do with him? dress him in my apparel

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and make him my waiting-gentlewoman? He that hath a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: beard is less than a man: and he that is more than

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a youth is not for me, and he that is less than a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: man, I am not for him: therefore, I will even take

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: sixpence in earnest of the bear-ward, and lead his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: apes into hell.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Well, then, go you into hell?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, but to the gate; and there will the devil meet

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his head, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: say 'Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: heaven; here's no place for you maids:' so deliver

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter for the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: heavens; he shows me where the bachelors sit, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: there live we as merry as the day is long.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: [To HERO]  Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: by your father.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yes, faith; it is my cousin's duty to make curtsy

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and say 'Father, as it please you.' But yet for all

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: make another curtsy and say 'Father, as it please

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: me.'

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Not till God make men of some other metal than

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: overmastered with a pierce of valiant dust? to make

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, uncle, I'll none: Adam's sons are my brethren;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and, truly, I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Daughter, remember what I told you: if the prince

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: not wooed in good time: if the prince be too

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: important, tell him there is measure in every thing

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, Hero:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a Scotch jig,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a measure, and a cinque pace: the first suit is hot

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: and hasty, like a Scotch jig, and full as

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: fantastical; the wedding, mannerly-modest, as a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: measure, full of state and ancientry; and then comes

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: repentance and, with his bad legs, falls into the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: cinque pace faster and faster, till he sink into his grave.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I have a good eye, uncle; I can see a church by daylight.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: All put on their masks

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: So you walk softly and look sweetly and say nothing,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I am yours for the walk; and especially when I walk away.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: With me in your company?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I may say so, when I please.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And when please you to say so?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: When I like your favour; for God defend the lute

speaker: HERO
text_entry: should be like the case!

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: My visor is Philemon's roof; within the house is Jove.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Speak low, if you speak love.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Drawing her aside

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Well, I would you did like me.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: So would not I, for your own sake; for I have many

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: ill-qualities.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Which is one?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: I say my prayers aloud.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: I love you the better: the hearers may cry, Amen.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: God match me with a good dancer!

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: done! Answer, clerk.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: No more words: the clerk is answered.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: I know you well enough; you are Signior Antonio.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: At a word, I am not.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: I know you by the waggling of your head.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: You could never do him so ill-well, unless you were

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: the very man. Here's his dry hand up and down: you

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: are he, you are he.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: At a word, I am not.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? Go to,

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: mum, you are he: graces will appear, and there's an

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: end.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Will you not tell me who told you so?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: No, you shall pardon me.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Not now.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: out of the 'Hundred Merry Tales:'--well this was

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Signior Benedick that said so.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: What's he?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I am sure you know him well enough.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Not I, believe me.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Did he never make you laugh?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I pray you, what is he?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Why, he is the prince's jester: a very dull fool;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: only his gift is in devising impossible slanders:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: none but libertines delight in him; and the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: commendation is not in his wit, but in his villany;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: for he both pleases men and angers them, and then

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the fleet: I would he had boarded me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: When I know the gentleman, I'll tell him what you say.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Do, do: he'll but break a comparison or two on me;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: strikes him into melancholy; and then there's a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: supper that night.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Music

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: We must follow the leaders.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In every good thing.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the next turning.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: withdrawn her father to break with him about it.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Are not you Signior Benedick?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: You know me well; I am he.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Signior, you are very near my brother in his love:

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: he is enamoured on Hero; I pray you, dissuade him

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: do the part of an honest man in it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: How know you he loves her?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I heard him swear his affection.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: So did I too; and he swore he would marry her to-night.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Come, let us to the banquet.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Exeunt DON JOHN and BORACHIO

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: 'Tis certain so; the prince wooes for himself.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Friendship is constant in all other things

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Save in the office and affairs of love:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Let every eye negotiate for itself

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And trust no agent; for beauty is a witch

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: This is an accident of hourly proof,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Re-enter BENEDICK

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Count Claudio?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yea, the same.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Come, will you go with me?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Whither?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Even to the next willow, about your own business,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: county. What fashion will you wear the garland of?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: about your neck, like an usurer's chain? or under

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: your arm, like a lieutenant's scarf? You must wear

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: it one way, for the prince hath got your Hero.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I wish him joy of her.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier: so they

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: sell bullocks. But did you think the prince would

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: have served you thus?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I pray you, leave me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Ho! now you strike like the blind man: 'twas the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: boy that stole your meat, and you'll beat the post.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If it will not be, I'll leave you.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: know me! The prince's fool! Ha? It may be I go

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: under that title because I am merry. Yea, but so I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: am apt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed: it

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: that puts the world into her person and so gives me

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: out. Well, I'll be revenged as I may.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Re-enter DON PEDRO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Now, signior, where's the count? did you see him?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: warren: I told him, and I think I told him true,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: that your grace had got the good will of this young

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: lady; and I offered him my company to a willow-tree,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: To be whipped! What's his fault?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The flat transgression of a schoolboy, who, being

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: companion, and he steals it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? The

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: transgression is in the stealer.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and the garland too; for the garland he might have

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you, who, as I take it, have stolen his birds' nest.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the owner.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you say honestly.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: gentleman that danced with her told her she is much

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: wronged by you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: O, she misused me past the endurance of a block!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: an oak but with one green leaf on it would have

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: answered her; my very visor began to assume life and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: scold with her. She told me, not thinking I had been

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: myself, that I was the prince's jester, that I was

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: duller than a great thaw; huddling jest upon jest

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting at

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: if her breath were as terrible as her terminations,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: there were no living near her; she would infect to

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the north star. I would not marry her, though she

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: were endowed with all that Adam bad left him before

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the fire too. Come, talk not of her: you shall find

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: some scholar would conjure her; for certainly, while

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: sanctuary; and people sin upon purpose, because they

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: would go thither; so, indeed, all disquiet, horror

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and perturbation follows her.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Look, here she comes.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Will your grace command me any service to the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: world's end? I will go on the slightest errand now

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on;

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Prester John's foot, fetch you a hair off the great

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Cham's beard, do you any embassage to the Pigmies,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rather than hold three words' conference with this

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: harpy. You have no employment for me?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: None, but to desire your good company.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: O God, sir, here's a dish I love not: I cannot

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: endure my Lady Tongue.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Signior Benedick.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile; and I gave

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: him use for it, a double heart for his single one:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: marry, once before he won it of me with false dice,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: therefore your grace may well say I have lost it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: should prove the mother of fools. I have brought

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, how now, count! wherefore are you sad?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Not sad, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: How then? sick?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Neither, my lord.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: The count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: well; but civil count, civil as an orange, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: something of that jealous complexion.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I' faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: though, I'll be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: fair Hero is won: I have broke with her father,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: and his good will obtained: name the day of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: marriage, and God give thee joy!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and an

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: grace say Amen to it.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Speak, count, 'tis your cue.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady, as

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: you and dote upon the exchange.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yea, my lord; I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: ear that he is in her heart.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And so she doth, cousin.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to the

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: world but I, and I am sunburnt; I may sit in a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: corner and cry heigh-ho for a husband!

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I would rather have one of your father's getting.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you? Your

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Will you have me, lady?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, my lord, unless I might have another for

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: working-days: your grace is too costly to wear

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: every day. But, I beseech your grace, pardon me: I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: was born to speak all mirth and no matter.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: becomes you; for, out of question, you were born in

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: a merry hour.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, sure, my lord, my mother cried; but then there

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: was a star danced, and under that was I born.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Cousins, God give you joy!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your grace's pardon.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: There's little of the melancholy element in her, my

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps, and

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: not ever sad then; for I have heard my daughter say,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: herself with laughing.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: they would talk themselves mad.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To-morrow, my lord: time goes on crutches till love

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: have all his rites.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: seven-night; and a time too brief, too, to have all

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: things answer my mind.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Hercules' labours; which is, to bring Signior

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: affection the one with the other. I would fain have

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: you three will but minister such assistance as I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: shall give you direction.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: nights' watchings.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And I, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And you too, gentle Hero?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my

speaker: HERO
text_entry: cousin to a good husband.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I know. Thus far can I praise him; he is of a noble

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: strain, of approved valour and confirmed honesty. I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: will teach you how to humour your cousin, that she

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: shall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: two helps, will so practise on Benedick that, in

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Cupid is no longer an archer: hi s glory shall be

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: ours, for we are the only love-gods. Go in with me,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: and I will tell you my drift.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: SCENE II. The same.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter DON JOHN and BORACHIO

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: daughter of Leonato.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: medicinable to me: I am sick in displeasure to him,

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: evenly with mine. How canst thou cross this marriage?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly that no

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: dishonesty shall appear in me.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Show me briefly how.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: I think I told your lordship a year since, how much

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: gentlewoman to Hero.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I remember.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: What life is in that, to be the death of this marriage?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: the prince your brother; spare not to tell him that

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: he hath wronged his honour in marrying the renowned

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Claudio--whose estimation do you mightily hold

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: up--to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: What proof shall I make of that?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Proof enough to misuse the prince, to vex Claudio,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to undo Hero and kill Leonato. Look you for any

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: other issue?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Only to despite them, I will endeavour any thing.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Go, then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: the Count Claudio alone: tell them that you know

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal both to the

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: prince and Claudio, as,--in love of your brother's

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: semblance of a maid,--that you have discovered

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: thus. They will scarcely believe this without trial:

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: offer them instances; which shall bear no less

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: likelihood than to see me at her chamber-window,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Claudio; and bring them to see this the very night

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: before the intended wedding,--for in the meantime I

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: absent,--and there shall appear such seeming truth

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall be called

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: assurance and all the preparation overthrown.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: it in practise. Be cunning in the working this, and

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: thy fee is a thousand ducats.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: shall not shame me.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: SCENE III. LEONATO'S orchard.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Enter BENEDICK

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Boy!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter Boy

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Signior?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In my chamber-window lies a book: bring it hither

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to me in the orchard.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: I am here already, sir.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I know that; but I would have thee hence, and here again.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit Boy

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: another man is a fool when he dedicates his

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: such shallow follies in others, become the argument

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: of his own scorn by failing in love: and such a man

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: is Claudio. I have known when there was no music

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with him but the drum and the fife; and now had he

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rather hear the tabour and the pipe: I have known

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: when he would have walked ten mile a-foot to see a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: good armour; and now will he lie ten nights awake,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and a soldier; and now is he turned orthography; his

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: be sworn, but love may transform me to an oyster; but

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her;

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: fair, or I'll   never look on her; mild, or come not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: be of what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Withdraws

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, shall we hear this music?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, very well, my lord: the music ended,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Enter BALTHASAR with Music

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: To slander music any more than once.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: It is the witness still of excellency

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: To put a strange face on his own perfection.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Since many a wooer doth commence his suit

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Yet will he swear he loves.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Now, pray thee, come;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Do it in notes.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Note this before my notes;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Air

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: all's done.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The Song

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Men were deceivers ever,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: One foot in sea and one on shore,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: To one thing constant never:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Then sigh not so, but let them go,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And be you blithe and bonny,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Converting all your sounds of woe

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Into Hey nonny, nonny.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Of dumps so dull and heavy;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: The fraud of men was ever so,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Since summer first was leafy:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Then sigh not so,  and c.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my troth, a good song.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And an ill singer, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest well enough for a shift.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: they would have hanged him: and I pray God his bad

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: voice bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: night-raven, come what plague could have come after

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: get us some excellent music; for to-morrow night we

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber-window.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: The best I can, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Do so: farewell.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exit BALTHASAR

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: to-day, that your niece Beatrice was in love with

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Signior Benedick?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, ay: stalk on. stalk on; the fowl sits. I did

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: never think that lady would have loved any man.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: of it but that she loves him with an enraged

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: affection: it is past the infinite of thought.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: May be she doth but counterfeit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Faith, like enough.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O God, counterfeit! There was never counterfeit of

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: passion came so near the life of passion as she

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: discovers it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What effects, my lord? She will sit you, you heard

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: my daughter tell you how.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: She did, indeed.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: How, how, pray you? You amaze me: I would have I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: thought her spirit had been invincible against all

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: assaults of affection.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: against Benedick.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I should think this a gull, but that the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: sure, hide himself in such reverence.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: 'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: 'Shall

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I,' says she, 'that have so oft encountered him

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: with scorn, write to him that I love him?'

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: This says she now when she is beginning to write to

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: him; for she'll be up twenty times a night, and

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: pretty jest your daughter told us of.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: railed at herself, that she should be so immodest

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: to write to one that she knew would flout her; 'I

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: measure him,' says she, 'by my own spirit; for I

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though I

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: love him, I should.'

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; 'O

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: sweet Benedick! God give me patience!'

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: She doth indeed; my daughter says so: and the

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: is sometime afeared she will do a desperate outrage

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: to herself: it is very true.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: other, if she will not discover it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To what end? He would make but a sport of it and

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: torment the poor lady worse.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: excellent sweet lady; and, out of all suspicion,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: she is virtuous.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And she is exceeding wise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: In every thing but in loving Benedick.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: the victory. I am sorry for her, as I have just

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: cause, being her uncle and her guardian.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me: I would

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: have daffed all other respects and made her half

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and hear

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: what a' will say.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Were it good, think you?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says she

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: will die, if he love her not, and she will die, ere

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: she make her love known, and she will die, if he woo

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: her, rather than she will bate one breath of her

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: accustomed crossness.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: She doth well: if she should make tender of her

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: He is a very proper man.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And I take him to be valiant.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: them with a most Christian-like fear.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If he do fear God, a' must necessarily keep peace:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: quarrel with fear and trembling.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And so will he do; for the man doth fear God,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: he will make. Well I am sorry for your niece. Shall

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: we go seek Benedick, and tell him of her love?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: good counsel.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out first.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: let it cool the while. I love Benedick well; and I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: how much he is unworthy so good a lady.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: trust my expectation.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Let there be the same net spread for her; and that

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry. The

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: another's dotage, and no such matter: that's the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: scene that I would see, which will be merely a

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: dumb-show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: [Coming forward]  This can be no trick: the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: conference was sadly borne. They have the truth of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: this from Hero. They seem to pity the lady: it

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: seems her affections have their full bent. Love me!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censured:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the love come from her; they say too that she will

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rather die than give any sign of affection. I did

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: never think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: are they that hear their detractions and can put

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: them to mending. They say the lady is fair; 'tis a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous; 'tis

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: no great argument of her folly, for I will be

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: horribly in love with her. I may chance have some

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: because I have railed so long against marriage: but

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: doth not the appetite alter? a man loves the meat

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the brain awe a man from the career of his humour?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: she's a fair lady: I do spy some marks of love in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: her.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter BEATRICE

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I would

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: not have come.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: You take pleasure then in the message?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: point and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: signior: fare you well.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Ha! 'Against my will I am sent to bid you come in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to dinner;' there's a double meaning in that 'I took

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: no more pains for those thanks than you took pains

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to thank me.' that's as much as to say, Any pains

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: that I take for you is as easy as thanks. If I do

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: SCENE I. LEONATO'S garden.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter HERO, MARGARET, and URSULA

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Proposing with the prince and Claudio:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And bid her steal into the pleached bower,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Where honeysuckles, ripen'd by the sun,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Forbid the sun to enter, like favourites,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Made proud by princes, that advance their pride

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: To listen our purpose.  This is thy office;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: As we do trace this alley up and down,

speaker: HERO
