text_entry: Our talk must only be of Benedick.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: When I do name him, let it be thy part

speaker: HERO
text_entry: To praise him more than ever man did merit:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: My talk to thee must be how Benedick

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: That only wounds by hearsay.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Enter BEATRICE, behind

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Now begin;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: And greedily devour the treacherous bait:

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: So angle we for Beatrice; who even now

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Is couched in the woodbine coverture.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Approaching the bower

speaker: HERO
text_entry: No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I know her spirits are as coy and wild

speaker: HERO
text_entry: As haggerds of the rock.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: But are you sure

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: So says the prince and my new-trothed lord.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: To wish him wrestle with affection,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And never to let Beatrice know of it.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Deserve as full as fortunate a bed

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: O god of love! I know he doth deserve

speaker: HERO
text_entry: As much as may be yielded to a man:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: But Nature never framed a woman's heart

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Misprising what they look on, and her wit

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Values itself so highly that to her

speaker: HERO
text_entry: All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Nor take no shape nor project of affection,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: She is so self-endeared.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Sure, I think so;

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: And therefore certainly it were not good

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: But she would spell him backward: if fair-faced,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antique,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: If low, an agate very vilely cut;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;

speaker: HERO
text_entry: If silent, why, a block moved with none.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: So turns she every man the wrong side out

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And never gives to truth and virtue that

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: No, not to be so odd and from all fashions

speaker: HERO
text_entry: As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Out of myself, press me to death with wit.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: It were a better death than die with mocks,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Which is as bad as die with tickling.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: No; rather I will go to Benedick

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And counsel him to fight against his passion.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders

speaker: HERO
text_entry: To stain my cousin with: one doth not know

speaker: HERO
text_entry: How much an ill word may empoison liking.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: She cannot be so much without true judgment--

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Having so swift and excellent a wit

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: As she is prized to have--as to refuse

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: He is the only man of Italy.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Always excepted my dear Claudio.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: For shape, for bearing, argument and valour,

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Goes foremost in report through Italy.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: When are you married, madam?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: She's limed, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: If it proves so, then loving goes by haps:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Exeunt HERO and URSULA

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: [Coming forward]

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu!

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No glory lives behind the back of such.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: To bind our loves up in a holy band;

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: For others say thou dost deserve, and I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Believe it better than reportingly.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: then go I toward Arragon.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: vouchsafe me.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: of your marriage as to show a child his new coat

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: bow-string and the little hangman dare not shoot at

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: him; he hath a heart as sound as a bell and his

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks his

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: tongue speaks.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: So say I methinks you are sadder.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I hope he be in love.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood in

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: he wants money.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I have the toothache.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Draw it.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Hang it!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What! sigh for the toothache?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Where is but a humour or a worm.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yet say I, he is in love.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: a fancy that he hath to strange disguises; as, to be

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: a Dutchman today, a Frenchman to-morrow, or in the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: shape of two countries at once, as, a German from

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: believing old signs: a' brushes his hat o'

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: mornings; what should that bode?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: and the old ornament of his cheek hath already

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: stuffed tennis-balls.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Nay, a' rubs himself with civet: can you smell him

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: out by that?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And when was he wont to wash his face?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: what they say of him.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: a lute-string and now governed by stops.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: conclude he is in love.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Nay, but I know who loves him.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: all, dies for him.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: or nine wise words to speak to you, which these

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hobby-horses must not hear.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exeunt BENEDICK and LEONATO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: played their parts with Beatrice; and then the two

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: bears will not bite one another when they meet.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Enter DON JOHN

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: My lord and brother, God save you!

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good den, brother.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: In private?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear; for

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: what I would speak of concerns him.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What's the matter?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: [To CLAUDIO]  Means your lordship to be married

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: to-morrow?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You know he does.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: You may think I love you not: let that appear

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: your ensuing marriage;--surely suit ill spent and

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: labour ill bestowed.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, what's the matter?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: shortened, for she has been too long a talking of,

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: the lady is disloyal.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Who, Hero?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Even she; Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Disloyal?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness; I

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: could say she were worse: think you of a worse

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: further warrant: go but with me to-night, you shall

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: see her chamber-window entered, even the night

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: before her wedding-day: if you love her then,

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: to-morrow wed her; but it would better fit your honour

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: to change your mind.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: May this be so?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I will not think it.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: that you know: if you will follow me, I will show

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: you enough; and when you have seen more and heard

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: more, proceed accordingly.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If I see any thing to-night why I should not marry

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: her to-morrow in the congregation, where I should

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: wed, there will I shame her.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: with thee to disgrace her.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I will disparage her no farther till you are my

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: let the issue show itself.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: O day untowardly turned!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O mischief strangely thwarting!

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: O plague right well prevented! so will you say when

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: you have seen the sequel.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: SCENE III. A street.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Are you good men and true?

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: salvation, body and soul.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: they should have any allegiance in them, being

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: chosen for the prince's watch.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: First, who think you the most desertless man to be

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: constable?

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole; for they can

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: write and read.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Come hither, neighbour Seacole. God hath blessed

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man is

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: the gift of fortune; but to write and read comes by nature.

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Both which, master constable,--

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and make

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: no boast of it; and for your writing and reading,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: let that appear when there is no need of such

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: vanity. You are thought here to be the most

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: senseless and fit man for the constable of the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: watch; therefore bear you the lantern. This is your

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: to bid any man stand, in the prince's name.

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: How if a' will not stand?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go; and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: presently call the rest of the watch together and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: thank God you are rid of a knave.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: of the prince's subjects.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: True, and they are to meddle with none but the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: prince's subjects. You shall also make no noise in

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: We will rather sleep than talk: we know what

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: belongs to a watch.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: watchman; for I cannot see how sleeping should

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: offend: only, have a care that your bills be not

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: stolen. Well, you are to call at all the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: ale-houses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: How if they will not?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober: if

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: they make you not then the better answer, you may

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: say they are not the men you took them for.

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: Well, sir.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: of your office, to be no true man; and, for such

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: why the more is for your honesty.

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: hands on him?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Truly, by your office, you may; but I think they

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: show himself what he is and steal out of your company.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: a man who hath any honesty in him.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: to the nurse and bid her still it.

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Why, then, depart in peace, and let the child wake

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: her with crying; for the ewe that will not hear her

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: lamb when it baes will never answer a calf when he bleats.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: 'Tis very true.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: This is the end of the charge:--you, constable, are

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: to present the prince's own person: if you meet the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: prince in the night, you may stay him.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Nay, by'r our lady, that I think a' cannot.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Five shillings to one on't, with any man that knows

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: the statutes, he may stay him: marry, not without

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: the prince be willing; for, indeed, the watch ought

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: to offend no man; and it is an offence to stay a

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: man against his will.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: By'r lady, I think it be so.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Ha, ha, ha! Well, masters, good night: an there be

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: any matter of weight chances, call up me: keep your

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: fellows' counsels and your own; and good night.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Come, neighbour.

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit here

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: upon the church-bench till two, and then all to bed.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you watch

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: about Signior Leonato's door; for the wedding being

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: there to-morrow, there is a great coil to-night.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Adieu: be vigitant, I beseech you.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Exeunt DOGBERRY and VERGES

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Enter BORACHIO and CONRADE

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: What Conrade!

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: [Aside]  Peace! stir not.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Conrade, I say!

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Here, man; I am at thy elbow.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Mass, and my elbow itched; I thought there would a

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: scab follow.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: I will owe thee an answer for that: and now forward

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: with thy tale.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Stand thee close, then, under this pent-house, for

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: it drizzles rain; and I will, like a true drunkard,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: utter all to thee.

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: [Aside]  Some treason, masters: yet stand close.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Is it possible that any villany should be so dear?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: villany should be so rich; for when rich villains

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: price they will.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: I wonder at it.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: nothing to a man.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Yes, it is apparel.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: I mean, the fashion.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Tush! I may as well say the fool's the fool. But

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: is?

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: [Aside]  I know that Deformed; a' has been a vile

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: thief this seven year; a' goes up and down like a

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: gentleman: I remember his name.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Didst thou not hear somebody?

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: No; 'twas the vane on the house.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: fashion is? how giddily a' turns about all the hot

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: in the reeky painting, sometime like god Bel's

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: priests in the old church-window, sometime like the

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten tapestry,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: All this I see; and I see that the fashion wears

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: out more apparel than the man. But art not thou

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Not so, neither: but know that I have to-night

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: name of Hero: she leans me out at her mistress'

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: chamber-window, bids me a thousand times good

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: night,--I tell this tale vilely:--I should first

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: tell thee how the prince, Claudio and my master,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: planted and placed and possessed by my master Don

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Two of them did, the prince and Claudio; but the

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: by my villany, which did confirm any slander that

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged; swore

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: he would meet her, as he was appointed, next morning

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: at the temple, and there, before the whole

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: congregation, shame her with what he saw o'er night

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: and send her home again without a husband.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: We charge you, in the prince's name, stand!

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Call up the right master constable. We have here

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: ever was known in the commonwealth.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: And one Deformed is one of them: I know him; a'

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: wears a lock.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Masters, masters,--

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Masters,--

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: Never speak: we charge you let us obey you to go with us.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: up of these men's bills.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, we'll obey you.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: SCENE IV. HERO's apartment.

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Enter HERO, MARGARET, and URSULA

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire

speaker: HERO
text_entry: her to rise.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: I will, lady.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And bid her come hither.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Well.

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Troth, I think your other rabato were better.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: By my troth, 's not so good; and I warrant your

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: cousin will say so.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: My cousin's a fool, and thou art another: I'll wear

speaker: HERO
text_entry: none but this.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: were a thought browner; and your gown's a most rare

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: fashion, i' faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan's

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: gown that they praise so.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: O, that exceeds, they say.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: By my troth, 's but a night-gown in respect of

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: yours: cloth o' gold, and cuts, and laced with

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: and skirts, round underborne with a bluish tinsel:

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: but for a fine, quaint, graceful and excellent

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: fashion, yours is worth ten on 't.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is

speaker: HERO
text_entry: exceeding heavy.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: 'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: marriage honourable in a beggar? Is not your lord

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: honourable without marriage? I think you would have

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: me say, 'saving your reverence, a husband:' and bad

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'll offend

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: nobody: is there any harm in 'the heavier for a

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: husband'? None, I think, and it be the right husband

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: and the right wife; otherwise 'tis light, and not

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice else; here she comes.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Enter BEATRICE

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Good morrow, coz.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Why how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Clap's into 'Light o' love;' that goes without a

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: burden: do you sing it, and I'll dance it.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Ye light o' love, with your heels! then, if your

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: husband have stables enough, you'll see he shall

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: lack no barns.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: 'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; tis time you were

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill: heigh-ho!

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: For the letter that begins them all, H.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Well, and you be not turned Turk, there's no more

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: sailing by the star.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: What means the fool, trow?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Nothing I; but God send every one their heart's desire!

speaker: HERO
text_entry: These gloves the count sent me; they are an

speaker: HERO
text_entry: excellent perfume.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I am stuffed, cousin; I cannot smell.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: A maid, and stuffed! there's goodly catching of cold.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: O, God help me! God help me! how long have you

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: professed apprehension?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: cap. By my troth, I am sick.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Get you some of this distilled Carduus Benedictus,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: and lay it to your heart: it is the only thing for a qualm.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Benedictus! why Benedictus? you have some moral in

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: this Benedictus.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Moral! no, by my troth, I have no moral meaning; I

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: meant, plain holy-thistle. You may think perchance

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: that I think you are in love: nay, by'r lady, I am

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: are in love or that you will be in love or that you

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: now is he become a man: he swore he would never

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: his meat without grudging: and how you may be

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: converted I know not, but methinks you look with

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: your eyes as other women do.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Not a false gallop.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Re-enter URSULA

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Madam, withdraw: the prince, the count, Signior

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: town, are come to fetch you to church.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HERO
text_entry: SCENE V. Another room in LEONATO'S house.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Enter LEONATO, with DOGBERRY and VERGES

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: that decerns you nearly.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Brief, I pray you; for you see it is a busy time with me.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Marry, this it is, sir.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What is it, my good friends?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: matter: an old man, sir, and his wits are not so

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: blunt as, God help, I would desire they were; but,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: that is an old man and no honester than I.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Comparisons are odorous: palabras, neighbour Verges.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Neighbours, you are tedious.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: poor duke's officers; but truly, for mine own part,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis; for

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: I hear as good exclamation on your worship as of any

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: man in the city; and though I be but a poor man, I

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: am glad to hear it.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: And so am I.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I would fain know what you have to say.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Marry, sir, our watch to-night, excepting your

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: worship's presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: knaves as any in Messina.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: A good old man, sir; he will be talking: as they

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: say, when the age is in, the wit is out: God help

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: us! it is a world to see. Well said, i' faith,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: neighbour Verges: well, God's a good man; an two men

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An honest

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: soul, i' faith, sir; by my troth he is, as ever

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: broke bread; but God is to be worshipped; all men

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: are not alike; alas, good neighbour!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Indeed, neighbour, he comes too short of you.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Gifts that God gives.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I must leave you.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: One word, sir: our watch, sir, have indeed

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: have them this morning examined before your worship.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Take their examination yourself and bring it me: I

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: It shall be suffigance.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: her husband.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I'll wait upon them: I am ready.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Exeunt LEONATO and Messenger

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole;

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the gaol: we

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: are now to examination these men.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: And we must do it wisely.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you; here's

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: that shall drive some of them to a non-come: only

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: get the learned writer to set down our

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: excommunication and meet me at the gaol.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: SCENE I. A church.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, LEONATO, FRIAR FRANCIS, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, HERO, BEATRICE, and Attendants

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Come, Friar Francis, be brief; only to the plain

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: form of marriage, and you shall recount their

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: particular duties afterwards.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: No.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To be married to her: friar, you come to marry her.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I do.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: If either of you know any inward impediment why you

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: should not be conjoined, charge you, on your souls,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: to utter it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Know you any, Hero?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: None, my lord.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Know you any, count?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I dare make his answer, none.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: do, not knowing what they do!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: How now! interjections? Why, then, some be of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: laughing, as, ah, ha, he!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Stand thee by, friar. Father, by your leave:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Will you with free and unconstrained soul

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Give me this maid, your daughter?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And what have I to give you back, whose worth

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Nothing, unless you render her again.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Sweet prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: There, Leonato, take her back again:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Give not this rotten orange to your friend;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: She's but the sign and semblance of her honour.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Behold how like a maid she blushes here!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, what authority and show of truth

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Can cunning sin cover itself withal!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Comes not that blood as modest evidence

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: All you that see her, that she were a maid,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: By these exterior shows? But she is none:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What do you mean, my lord?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Not to be married,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Have vanquish'd the resistance of her youth,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And made defeat of her virginity,--

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I know what you would say: if I have known her,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: You will say she did embrace me as a husband,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And so extenuate the 'forehand sin:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: No, Leonato,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I never tempted her with word too large;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But, as a brother to his sister, show'd

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Bashful sincerity and comely love.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And seem'd I ever otherwise to you?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Out on thee! Seeming! I will write against it:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: You seem to me as Dian in her orb,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But you are more intemperate in your blood

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Than Venus, or those pamper'd animals

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That rage in savage sensuality.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Sweet prince, why speak not you?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What should I speak?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I stand dishonour'd, that have gone about

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: To link my dear friend to a common stale.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: This looks not like a nuptial.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: True! O God!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Leonato, stand I here?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Is this the prince? is this the prince's brother?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Is this face Hero's? are our eyes our own?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: All this is so: but what of this, my lord?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Let me but move one question to your daughter;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And, by that fatherly and kindly power

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: O, God defend me! how am I beset!

speaker: HERO
text_entry: What kind of catechising call you this?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To make you answer truly to your name.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Is it not Hero? Who can blot that name

speaker: HERO
text_entry: With any just reproach?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Marry, that can Hero;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hero itself can blot out Hero's virtue.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: What man was he talk'd with you yesternight

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Now, if you are a maid, answer to this.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: I talk'd with no man at that hour, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, then are you no maiden. Leonato,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I am sorry you must hear: upon mine honour,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Myself, my brother and this grieved count

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Talk with a ruffian at her chamber-window

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Confess'd the vile encounters they have had

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: A thousand times in secret.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Fie, fie! they are not to be named, my lord,

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Not to be spoke of;

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: There is not chastity enough in language

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Without offence to utter them. Thus, pretty lady,

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O Hero, what a Hero hadst thou been,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If half thy outward graces had been placed

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But fare thee well, most foul, most fair! farewell,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Thou pure impiety and impious purity!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For thee I'll lock up all the gates of love,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And on my eyelids shall conjecture hang,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And never shall it more be gracious.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hath no man's dagger here a point for me?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: HERO swoons

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Why, how now, cousin! wherefore sink you down?

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Come, let us go. These things, come thus to light,

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Smother her spirits up.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Exeunt DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, and CLAUDIO

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: How doth the lady?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Dead, I think. Help, uncle!

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Hero! why, Hero! Uncle! Signior Benedick! Friar!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O Fate! take not away thy heavy hand.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Death is the fairest cover for her shame

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That may be wish'd for.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: How now, cousin Hero!

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Have comfort, lady.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Dost thou look up?

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Yea, wherefore should she not?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Wherefore! Why, doth not every earthly thing

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The story that is printed in her blood?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Do not live, Hero; do not ope thine eyes:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: For, did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Myself would, on the rearward of reproaches,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Strike at thy life. Grieved I, I had but one?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Chid I for that at frugal nature's frame?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, one too much by thee! Why had I one?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Why had I not with charitable hand

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Took up a beggar's issue at my gates,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Who smirch'd thus and mired with infamy,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I might have said 'No part of it is mine;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: This shame derives itself from unknown loins'?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But mine and mine I loved and mine I praised

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And mine that I was proud on, mine so much

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That I myself was to myself not mine,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Valuing of her,--why, she, O, she is fallen

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Into a pit of ink, that the wide sea

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hath drops too few to wash her clean again

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And salt too little which may season give

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To her foul-tainted flesh!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sir, sir, be patient.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: For my part, I am so attired in wonder,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I know not what to say.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: O, on my soul, my cousin is belied!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, truly not; although, until last night,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I have this twelvemonth been her bedfellow.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Confirm'd, confirm'd! O, that is stronger made

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Which was before barr'd up with ribs of iron!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Would the two princes lie, and Claudio lie,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Who loved her so, that, speaking of her foulness,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Wash'd it with tears? Hence from her! let her die.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Hear me a little;

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: For I have only been silent so long

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And given way unto this course of fortune.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: By noting of the lady I have mark'd

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: A thousand blushing apparitions

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: In angel whiteness beat away those blushes;

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And in her eye there hath appear'd a fire,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: To burn the errors that these princes hold

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool;

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Trust not my reading nor my observations,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Which with experimental seal doth warrant

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: The tenor of my book; trust not my age,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: My reverence, calling, nor divinity,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: If this sweet lady lie not guiltless here

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Under some biting error.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Friar, it cannot be.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thou seest that all the grace that she hath left

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Is that she will not add to her damnation

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: A sin of perjury; she not denies it:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Why seek'st thou then to cover with excuse

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That which appears in proper nakedness?

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Lady, what man is he you are accused of?

speaker: HERO
text_entry: They know that do accuse me; I know none:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: If I know more of any man alive

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Let all my sins lack mercy! O my father,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Prove you that any man with me conversed

speaker: HERO
text_entry: At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Maintain'd the change of words with any creature,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death!

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Two of them have the very bent of honour;

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And if their wisdoms be misled in this,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The practise of it lives in John the bastard,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Whose spirits toil in frame of villanies.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I know not. If they speak but truth of her,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honour,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The proudest of them shall well hear of it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nor age so eat up my invention,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nor fortune made such havoc of my means,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Both strength of limb and policy of mind,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Ability in means and choice of friends,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To quit me of them throughly.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Pause awhile,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And let my counsel sway you in this case.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Your daughter here the princes left for dead:

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Let her awhile be secretly kept in,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And publish it that she is dead indeed;

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Maintain a mourning ostentation

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And on your family's old monument

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Hang mournful epitaphs and do all rites

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: That appertain unto a burial.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What shall become of this? what will this do?

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Marry, this well carried shall on her behalf

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Change slander to remorse; that is some good:

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: But not for that dream I on this strange course,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: But on this travail look for greater birth.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: She dying, as it must so be maintain'd,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Upon the instant that she was accused,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Shall be lamented, pitied and excused

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Of every hearer: for it so falls out

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: That what we have we prize not to the worth

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Whiles we enjoy it, but being lack'd and lost,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Why, then we rack the value, then we find

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: The virtue that possession would not show us

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Whiles it was ours. So will it fare with Claudio:

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: When he shall hear she died upon his words,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: The idea of her life shall sweetly creep

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Into his study of imagination,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And every lovely organ of her life

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Shall come apparell'd in more precious habit,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: More moving-delicate and full of life,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Into the eye and prospect of his soul,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Than when she lived indeed; then shall he mourn,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: If ever love had interest in his liver,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And wish he had not so accused her,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: No, though he thought his accusation true.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Let this be so, and doubt not but success

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Will fashion the event in better shape

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Than I can lay it down in likelihood.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: But if all aim but this be levell'd false,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: The supposition of the lady's death

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Will quench the wonder of her infamy:

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: As best befits her wounded reputation,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: In some reclusive and religious life,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Out of all eyes, tongues, minds and injuries.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And though you know my inwardness and love

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Is very much unto the prince and Claudio,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in this

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: As secretly and justly as your soul

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Should with your body.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Being that I flow in grief,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The smallest twine may lead me.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: 'Tis well consented: presently away;

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: For to strange sores strangely they strain the cure.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Come, lady, die to live: this wedding-day

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Perhaps is but prolong'd: have patience and endure.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Exeunt all but BENEDICK and BEATRICE

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I will not desire that.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You have no reason; I do it freely.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Ah, how much might the man deserve of me that would right her!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Is there any way to show such friendship?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: A very even way, but no such friend.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: May a man do it?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: It is a man's office, but not yours.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I do love nothing in the world so well as you: is

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: not that strange?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: As strange as the thing I know not. It were as

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: possible for me to say I loved nothing so well as

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: you: but believe me not; and yet I lie not; I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: confess nothing, nor I deny nothing. I am sorry for my cousin.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Do not swear, and eat it.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I will swear by it that you love me; and I will make

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: him eat it that says I love not you.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Will you not eat your word?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: With no sauce that can be devised to it. I protest

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I love thee.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Why, then, God forgive me!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: What offence, sweet Beatrice?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You have stayed me in a happy hour: I was about to

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: protest I loved you.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And do it with all thy heart.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I love you with so much of my heart that none is

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: left to protest.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Come, bid me do any thing for thee.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Kill Claudio.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Ha! not for the wide world.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You kill me to deny it. Farewell.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Tarry, sweet Beatrice.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I am gone, though I am here: there is no love in

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: you: nay, I pray you, let me go.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Beatrice,--

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: In faith, I will go.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: We'll be friends first.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: You dare easier be friends with me than fight with mine enemy.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Is Claudio thine enemy?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Is he not approved in the height a villain, that

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: hath slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman? O

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: that I were a man! What, bear her in hand until they

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: come to take hands; and then, with public

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: accusation, uncovered slander, unmitigated rancour,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: --O God, that I were a man! I would eat his heart

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: in the market-place.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Hear me, Beatrice,--

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Talk with a man out at a window! A proper saying!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Nay, but, Beatrice,--

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Sweet Hero! She is wronged, she is slandered, she is undone.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Beat--

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Princes and counties! Surely, a princely testimony,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a goodly count, Count Comfect; a sweet gallant,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: surely! O that I were a man for his sake! or that I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: had any friend would be a man for my sake! But

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: manhood is melted into courtesies, valour into

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: compliment, and men are only turned into tongue, and

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: trim ones too: he is now as valiant as Hercules

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: that only tells a lie and swears it. I cannot be a

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Tarry, good Beatrice. By this hand, I love thee.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged Hero?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yea, as sure as I have a thought or a soul.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enough, I am engaged; I will challenge him. I will

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: kiss your hand, and so I leave you. By this hand,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Claudio shall render me a dear account. As you

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hear of me, so think of me. Go, comfort your

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: cousin: I must say she is dead: and so, farewell.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: SCENE II. A prison.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and Sexton, in gowns; and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Is our whole dissembly appeared?

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: O, a stool and a cushion for the sexton.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: Which be the malefactors?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Marry, that am I and my partner.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Nay, that's certain; we have the exhibition to examine.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: But which are the offenders that are to be

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: examined? let them come before master constable.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Yea, marry, let them come before me. What is your

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: name, friend?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Borachio.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Pray, write down, Borachio. Yours, sirrah?

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Write down, master gentleman Conrade. Masters, do

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: you serve God?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Yea, sir, we hope.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Write down, that they hope they serve God: and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: write God first; for God defend but God should go

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: before such villains! Masters, it is proved already

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: that you are little better than false knaves; and it

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: will go near to be thought so shortly. How answer

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: you for yourselves?

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Marry, sir, we say we are none.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: A marvellous witty fellow, I assure you: but I

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: will go about with him. Come you hither, sirrah; a

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: word in your ear: sir, I say to you, it is thought

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: you are false knaves.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Sir, I say to you we are none.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Well, stand aside. 'Fore God, they are both in a

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: tale. Have you writ down, that they are none?

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: Master constable, you go not the way to examine:

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: you must call forth the watch that are their accusers.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Yea, marry, that's the eftest way. Let the watch

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: come forth. Masters, I charge you, in the prince's

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: name, accuse these men.

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: This man said, sir, that Don John, the prince's

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: brother, was a villain.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Write down Prince John a villain. Why, this is flat

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: perjury, to call a prince's brother villain.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Master constable,--

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Pray thee, fellow, peace: I do not like thy look,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: I promise thee.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: What heard you him say else?

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of

speaker: Second Watchman
text_entry: Don John for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Flat burglary as ever was committed.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Yea, by mass, that it is.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: What else, fellow?

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: And that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words, to

speaker: First Watchman
text_entry: disgrace Hero before the whole assembly. and not marry her.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: O villain! thou wilt be condemned into everlasting

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: redemption for this.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: What else?

speaker: Watchman
text_entry: This is all.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: And this is more, masters, than you can deny.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away;

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: Hero was in this manner accused, in this very manner

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: refused, and upon the grief of this suddenly died.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: Master constable, let these men be bound, and

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: brought to Leonato's: I will go before and show

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: him their examination.

speaker: Sexton
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Come, let them be opinioned.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Let them be in the hands--

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Off, coxcomb!

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: God's my life, where's the sexton? let him write

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: down the prince's officer coxcomb. Come, bind them.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Thou naughty varlet!

speaker: CONRADE
text_entry: Away! you are an ass, you are an ass.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Dost thou not suspect my place? dost thou not

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: suspect my years? O that he were here to write me

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: down an ass! But, masters, remember that I am an

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: ass; though it be not written down, yet forget not

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: that I am an ass. No, thou villain, thou art full of

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: piety, as shall be proved upon thee by good witness.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: I am a wise fellow, and, which is more, an officer,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: and, which is more, a householder, and, which is

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Messina, and one that knows the law, go to; and a

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: rich fellow enough, go to; and a fellow that hath

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: had losses, and one that hath two gowns and every

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: thing handsome about him. Bring him away. O that

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: I had been writ down an ass!

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: SCENE I. Before LEONATO'S house.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Enter LEONATO and ANTONIO

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And 'tis not wisdom thus to second grief

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Against yourself.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I pray thee, cease thy counsel,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Which falls into mine ears as profitless

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: As water in a sieve: give not me counsel;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nor let no comforter delight mine ear

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But such a one whose wrongs do suit with mine.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Bring me a father that so loved his child,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Whose joy of her is overwhelm'd like mine,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And bid him speak of patience;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And let it answer every strain for strain,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: As thus for thus and such a grief for such,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: In every lineament, branch, shape, and form:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Bid sorrow wag, cry 'hem!' when he should groan,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: With candle-wasters; bring him yet to me,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And I of him will gather patience.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But there is no such man: for, brother, men

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Can counsel and speak comfort to that grief

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Which they themselves not feel; but, tasting it,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Their counsel turns to passion, which before

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Would give preceptial medicine to rage,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Charm ache with air and agony with words:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, no; 'tis all men's office to speak patience

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To those that wring under the load of sorrow,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But no man's virtue nor sufficiency

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To be so moral when he shall endure

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The like himself. Therefore give me no counsel:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I pray thee, peace. I will be flesh and blood;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: For there was never yet philosopher

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That could endure the toothache patiently,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: However they have writ the style of gods

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And made a push at chance and sufferance.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Make those that do offend you suffer too.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: There thou speak'st reason: nay, I will do so.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My soul doth tell me Hero is belied;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And that shall Claudio know; so shall the prince

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And all of them that thus dishonour her.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Here comes the prince and Claudio hastily.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good den, good den.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Good day to both of you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hear you. my lords,--

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: We have some haste, Leonato.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Some haste, my lord! well, fare you well, my lord:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Are you so hasty now? well, all is one.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: If he could right himself with quarreling,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Some of us would lie low.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Who wrongs him?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Marry, thou dost wrong me; thou dissembler, thou:--

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I fear thee not.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Marry, beshrew my hand,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If it should give your age such cause of fear:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In faith, my hand meant nothing to my sword.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Tush, tush, man; never fleer and jest at me:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I speak not like a dotard nor a fool,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: As under privilege of age to brag

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What I have done being young, or what would do

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Were I not old. Know, Claudio, to thy head,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thou hast so wrong'd mine innocent child and me

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That I am forced to lay my reverence by

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Do challenge thee to trial of a man.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I say thou hast belied mine innocent child;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And she lies buried with her ancestors;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, in a tomb where never scandal slept,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Save this of hers, framed by thy villany!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: My villany?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Thine, Claudio; thine, I say.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: You say not right, old man.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, my lord,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I'll prove it on his body, if he dare,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Despite his nice fence and his active practise,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: His May of youth and bloom of lustihood.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Away! I will not have to do with you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast kill'd my child:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If thou kill'st me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: But that's no matter; let him kill one first;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Win me and wear me; let him answer me.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Come, follow me, boy; come, sir boy, come, follow me:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Sir boy, I'll whip you from your foining fence;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Brother,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Content yourself. God knows I loved my niece;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And she is dead, slander'd to death by villains,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That dare as well answer a man indeed

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: As I dare take a serpent by the tongue:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Boys, apes, braggarts, Jacks, milksops!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Brother Antony,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Hold you content. What, man! I know them, yea,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Scrambling, out-facing, fashion-monging boys,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: That lie and cog and flout, deprave and slander,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Go anticly, show outward hideousness,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And speak off half a dozen dangerous words,

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst;

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And this is all.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But, brother Antony,--

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Come, 'tis no matter:

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Do not you meddle; let me deal in this.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: My heart is sorry for your daughter's death:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But, on my honour, she was charged with nothing

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But what was true and very full of proof.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, my lord,--

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I will not hear you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No? Come, brother; away! I will be heard.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Exeunt LEONATO and ANTONIO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: See, see; here comes the man we went to seek.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter BENEDICK

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Now, signior, what news?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Good day, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Welcome, signior: you are almost come to part

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: almost a fray.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: We had like to have had our two noses snapped off

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: with two old men without teeth.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Leonato and his brother. What thinkest thou? Had

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for them.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In a false quarrel there is no true valour. I came

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to seek you both.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: We have been up and down to seek thee; for we are

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: high-proof melancholy and would fain have it beaten

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: away. Wilt thou use thy wit?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: It is in my scabbard: shall I draw it?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Dost thou wear thy wit by thy side?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Never any did so, though very many have been beside

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: their wit. I will bid thee draw, as we do the

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: minstrels; draw, to pleasure us.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: As I am an honest man, he looks pale. Art thou

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: sick, or angry?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: What, courage, man! What though care killed a cat,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and you

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: charge it against me. I pray you choose another subject.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Nay, then, give him another staff: this last was

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: broke cross.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By this light, he changes more and more: I think

speaker: DON PEDRO
