text_entry: he be angry indeed.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: God bless me from a challenge!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: [Aside to CLAUDIO]  You are a villain; I jest not:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I will make it good how you dare, with what you

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: dare, and when you dare. Do me right, or I will

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: protest your cowardice. You have killed a sweet

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: lady, and her death shall fall heavy on you. Let me

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hear from you.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Well, I will meet you, so I may have good cheer.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What, a feast, a feast?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I' faith, I thank him; he hath bid me to a calf's

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: head and a capon; the which if I do not carve most

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: curiously, say my knife's naught. Shall I not find

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: a woodcock too?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sir, your wit ambles well; it goes easily.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I'll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: other day. I said, thou hadst a fine wit: 'True,'

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: said she, 'a fine little one.' 'No,' said I, 'a

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: great wit:' 'Right,' says she, 'a great gross one.'

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: 'Nay,' said I, 'a good wit:' 'Just,' said she, 'it

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: hurts nobody.' 'Nay,' said I, 'the gentleman

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: is wise:' 'Certain,' said she, 'a wise gentleman.'

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: 'Nay,' said I, 'he hath the tongues:' 'That I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: believe,' said she, 'for he swore a thing to me on

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: there's a double tongue; there's two tongues.' Thus

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: did she, an hour together, transshape thy particular

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: virtues: yet at last she concluded with a sigh, thou

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: wast the properest man in Italy.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For the which she wept heartily and said she cared

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: not.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Yea, that she did: but yet, for all that, an if she

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the old man's daughter told us all.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: All, all; and, moreover, God saw him when he was

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: hid in the garden.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But when shall we set the savage bull's horns on

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: the sensible Benedick's head?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yea, and text underneath, 'Here dwells Benedick the

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: married man'?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Fare you well, boy: you know my mind. I will leave

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you now to your gossip-like humour: you break jests

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: as braggarts do their blades, which God be thanked,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: hurt not. My lord, for your many courtesies I thank

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you: I must discontinue your company: your brother

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the bastard is fled from Messina: you have among

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you killed a sweet and innocent lady. For my Lord

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Lackbeard there, he and I shall meet: and, till

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: then, peace be with him.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He is in earnest.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In most profound earnest; and, I'll warrant you, for

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: the love of Beatrice.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And hath challenged thee.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Most sincerely.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: He is then a giant to an ape; but then is an ape a

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: doctor to such a man.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But, soft you, let me be: pluck up, my heart, and

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: be sad. Did he not say, my brother was fled?

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Enter DOGBERRY, VERGES, and the Watch, with CONRADE and BORACHIO

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Come you, sir: if justice cannot tame you, she

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance: nay,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: an you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: How now? two of my brother's men bound! Borachio

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: one!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hearken after their offence, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Officers, what offence have these men done?

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Marry, sir, they have committed false report;

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: moreover, they have spoken untruths; secondarily,

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: they are slanders; sixth and lastly, they have

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: belied a lady; thirdly, they have verified unjust

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: things; and, to conclude, they are lying knaves.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: First, I ask thee what they have done; thirdly, I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: ask thee what's their offence; sixth and lastly, why

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: they are committed; and, to conclude, what you lay

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: to their charge.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Rightly reasoned, and in his own division: and, by

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: my troth, there's one meaning well suited.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Who have you offended, masters, that you are thus

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: bound to your answer? this learned constable is

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: too cunning to be understood: what's your offence?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Sweet prince, let me go no farther to mine answer:

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: do you hear me, and let this count kill me. I have

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: deceived even your very eyes: what your wisdoms

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: could not discover, these shallow fools have brought

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to light: who in the night overheard me confessing

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to this man how Don John your brother incensed me

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to slander the Lady Hero, how you were brought into

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: the orchard and saw me court Margaret in Hero's

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: garments, how you disgraced her, when you should

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: marry her: my villany they have upon record; which

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: I had rather seal with my death than repeat over

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: to my shame. The lady is dead upon mine and my

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: master's false accusation; and, briefly, I desire

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: nothing but the reward of a villain.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Runs not this speech like iron through your blood?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I have drunk poison whiles he utter'd it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: But did my brother set thee on to this?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Yea, and paid me richly for the practise of it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He is composed and framed of treachery:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And fled he is upon this villany.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Sweet Hero! now thy image doth appear

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Come, bring away the plaintiffs: by this time our

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter:

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: and, masters, do not forget to specify, when time

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: and place shall serve, that I am an ass.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Here, here comes master Signior Leonato, and the

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Sexton too.

speaker: VERGES
text_entry: Re-enter LEONATO and ANTONIO, with the Sexton

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Which is the villain? let me see his eyes,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That, when I note another man like him,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I may avoid him: which of these is he?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Art thou the slave that with thy breath hast kill'd

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Mine innocent child?

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Yea, even I alone.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, not so, villain; thou beliest thyself:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Here stand a pair of honourable men;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: A third is fled, that had a hand in it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I thank you, princes, for my daughter's death:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Record it with your high and worthy deeds:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: 'Twas bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I know not how to pray your patience;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yet I must speak. Choose your revenge yourself;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Impose me to what penance your invention

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Can lay upon my sin: yet sinn'd I not

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: But in mistaking.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my soul, nor I:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And yet, to satisfy this good old man,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I would bend under any heavy weight

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That he'll enjoin me to.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That were impossible: but, I pray you both,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Possess the people in Messina here

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: How innocent she died; and if your love

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Can labour ought in sad invention,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And sing it to her bones, sing it to-night:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To-morrow morning come you to my house,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And since you could not be my son-in-law,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Be yet my nephew: my brother hath a daughter,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Almost the copy of my child that's dead,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And she alone is heir to both of us:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Give her the right you should have given her cousin,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And so dies my revenge.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O noble sir,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Your over-kindness doth wring tears from me!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I do embrace your offer; and dispose

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For henceforth of poor Claudio.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To-morrow then I will expect your coming;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To-night I take my leave. This naughty man

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Who I believe was pack'd in all this wrong,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Hired to it by your brother.

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: No, by my soul, she was not,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: But always hath been just and virtuous

speaker: BORACHIO
text_entry: In any thing that I do know by her.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Moreover, sir, which indeed is not under white and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: black, this plaintiff here, the offender, did call

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: me ass: I beseech you, let it be remembered in his

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: punishment. And also, the watch heard them talk of

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: one Deformed: they say be wears a key in his ear and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: a lock hanging by it, and borrows money in God's

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: name, the which he hath used so long and never paid

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: that now men grow hard-hearted and will lend nothing

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: for God's sake: pray you, examine him upon that point.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Your worship speaks like a most thankful and

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: reverend youth; and I praise God for you.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: There's for thy pains.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: God save the foundation!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: I leave an arrant knave with your worship; which I

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: beseech your worship to correct yourself, for the

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: example of others. God keep your worship! I wish

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: your worship well; God restore you to health! I

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: humbly give you leave to depart; and if a merry

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: meeting may be wished, God prohibit it! Come, neighbour.

speaker: DOGBERRY
text_entry: Exeunt DOGBERRY and VERGES

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Until to-morrow morning, lords, farewell.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Farewell, my lords: we look for you to-morrow.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: We will not fail.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To-night I'll mourn with Hero.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: [To the Watch]  Bring you these fellows on. We'll

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: talk with Margaret,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Exeunt, severally

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: SCENE II. LEONATO'S garden.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Enter BENEDICK and MARGARET, meeting

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Will you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beauty?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: shall come over it; for, in most comely truth, thou

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: deservest it.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: To have no man come over me! why, shall I always

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: keep below stairs?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Thy wit is as quick as the greyhound's mouth; it catches.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: And yours as blunt as the fencer's foils, which hit,

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: but hurt not.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: A most manly wit, Margaret; it will not hurt a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: woman: and so, I pray thee, call Beatrice: I give

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: thee the bucklers.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Give us the swords; we have bucklers of our own.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: pikes with a vice; and they are dangerous weapons for maids.

speaker: MARGARET
text_entry: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And therefore will come.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit MARGARET

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sings

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The god of love,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: That sits above,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And knows me, and knows me,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: How pitiful I deserve,--

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I mean in singing; but in loving, Leander the good

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: swimmer, Troilus the first employer of panders, and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: a whole bookful of these quondam carpet-mangers,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: whose names yet run smoothly in the even road of a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: blank verse, why, they were never so truly turned

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: over and over as my poor self in love. Marry, I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: cannot show it in rhyme; I have tried: I can find

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: out no rhyme to 'lady' but 'baby,' an innocent

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rhyme; for 'scorn,' 'horn,' a hard rhyme; for,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: 'school,' 'fool,' a babbling rhyme; very ominous

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: endings: no, I was not born under a rhyming planet,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: nor I cannot woo in festival terms.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter BEATRICE

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yea, signior, and depart when you bid me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: O, stay but till then!

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: 'Then' is spoken; fare you well now: and yet, ere

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I go, let me go with that I came; which is, with

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: knowing what hath passed between you and Claudio.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Only foul words; and thereupon I will kiss thee.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: foul breath, and foul breath is noisome; therefore I

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: will depart unkissed.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sense,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: so forcible is thy wit. But I must tell thee

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge; and either

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: him a coward. And, I pray thee now, tell me for

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: which of my bad parts didst thou first fall in love with me?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: For them all together; which maintained so politic

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: a state of evil that they will not admit any good

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: part to intermingle with them. But for which of my

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: good parts did you first suffer love for me?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Suffer love! a good epithet! I do suffer love

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: indeed, for I love thee against my will.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: In spite of your heart, I think; alas, poor heart!

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: If you spite it for my sake, I will spite it for

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: yours; for I will never love that which my friend hates.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: It appears not in this confession: there's not one

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: wise man among twenty that will praise himself.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the lime of good neighbours. If a man do not erect

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: in this age his own tomb ere he dies, he shall live

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: no longer in monument than the bell rings and the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: widow weeps.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: And how long is that, think you?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Question: why, an hour in clamour and a quarter in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rheum: therefore is it most expedient for the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: wise, if Don Worm, his conscience, find no

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of his

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: own virtues, as I am to myself. So much for

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: praiseworthy: and now tell me, how doth your cousin?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Very ill.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And how do you?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Very ill too.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Serve God, love me and mend. There will I leave

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: you too, for here comes one in haste.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter URSULA

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: Madam, you must come to your uncle. Yonder's old

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: coil at home: it is proved my Lady Hero hath been

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: falsely accused, the prince and Claudio mightily

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: abused; and Don John is the author of all, who is

speaker: URSULA
text_entry: fed and gone. Will you come presently?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Will you go hear this news, signior?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: buried in thy eyes; and moreover I will go with

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: thee to thy uncle's.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: SCENE III. A church.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and three or four with tapers

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Is this the monument of Leonato?

speaker: Lord
text_entry: It is, my lord.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: [Reading out of a scroll]

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Done to death by slanderous tongues

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Was the Hero that here lies:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Death, in guerdon of her wrongs,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Gives her fame which never dies.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: So the life that died with shame

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Lives in death with glorious fame.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hang thou there upon the tomb,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Praising her when I am dumb.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Now, music, sound, and sing your solemn hymn.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Pardon, goddess of the night,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Those that slew thy virgin knight;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For the which, with songs of woe,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Round about her tomb they go.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Midnight, assist our moan;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Help us to sigh and groan,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Heavily, heavily:

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Graves, yawn and yield your dead,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Till death be uttered,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Heavily, heavily.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Now, unto thy bones good night!

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yearly will I do this rite.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good morrow, masters; put your torches out:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The wolves have prey'd; and look, the gentle day,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Dapples the drowsy east with spots of grey.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Thanks to you all, and leave us: fare you well.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Good morrow, masters: each his several way.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And then to Leonato's we will go.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And Hymen now with luckier issue speed's

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Than this for whom we render'd up this woe.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: SCENE IV. A room in LEONATO'S house.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, BENEDICK, BEATRICE, MARGARET, URSULA, FRIAR FRANCIS, and HERO

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: So are the prince and Claudio, who accused her

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Upon the error that you heard debated:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: But Margaret was in some fault for this,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Although against her will, as it appears

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: In the true course of all the question.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And so am I, being else by faith enforced

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Well, daughter, and you gentle-women all,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And when I send for you, come hither mask'd.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Exeunt Ladies

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The prince and Claudio promised by this hour

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To visit me. You know your office, brother:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: You must be father to your brother's daughter

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: And give her to young Claudio.

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: Which I will do with confirm'd countenance.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: To do what, signior?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: To bind me, or undo me; one of them.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: That eye my daughter lent her: 'tis most true.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: The sight whereof I think you had from me,

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: From Claudio and the prince: but what's your will?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Your answer, sir, is enigmatical:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: But, for my will, my will is your good will

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: May stand with ours, this day to be conjoin'd

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In the state of honourable marriage:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In which, good friar, I shall desire your help.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My heart is with your liking.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And my help.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Here comes the prince and Claudio.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO and CLAUDIO, and two or three others

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Good morrow, prince; good morrow, Claudio:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: We here attend you. Are you yet determined

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: To-day to marry with my brother's daughter?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I'll hold my mind, were she an Ethiope.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Call her forth, brother; here's the friar ready.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Exit ANTONIO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Good morrow, Benedick. Why, what's the matter,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: That you have such a February face,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: So full of frost, of storm and cloudiness?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I think he thinks upon the savage bull.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Tush, fear not, man; we'll tip thy horns with gold

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: As once Europa did at lusty Jove,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: When he would play the noble beast in love.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Bull Jove, sir, had an amiable low;

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And some such strange bull leap'd your father's cow,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: And got a calf in that same noble feat

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For this I owe you: here comes other reckonings.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Re-enter ANTONIO, with the Ladies masked

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Which is the lady I must seize upon?

speaker: ANTONIO
text_entry: This same is she, and I do give you her.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Why, then she's mine. Sweet, let me see your face.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, that you shall not, till you take her hand

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Before this friar and swear to marry her.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Give me your hand: before this holy friar,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I am your husband, if you like of me.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And when I lived, I was your other wife:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Unmasking

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And when you loved, you were my other husband.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Another Hero!

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Nothing certainer:

speaker: HERO
text_entry: One Hero died defiled, but I do live,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And surely as I live, I am a maid.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: The former Hero! Hero that is dead!

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: All this amazement can I qualify:

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: When after that the holy rites are ended,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: I'll tell you largely of fair Hero's death:

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: Meantime let wonder seem familiar,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
text_entry: And to the chapel let us presently.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Soft and fair, friar. Which is Beatrice?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: [Unmasking]  I answer to that name. What is your will?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Do not you love me?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Why, no; no more than reason.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Why, then your uncle and the prince and Claudio

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Have been deceived; they swore you did.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Do not you love me?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Troth, no; no more than reason.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Why, then my cousin Margaret and Ursula

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Are much deceived; for they did swear you did.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: They swore that you were almost sick for me.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: 'Tis no such matter. Then you do not love me?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: No, truly, but in friendly recompense.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Come, cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And I'll be sworn upon't that he loves her;

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: For here's a paper written in his hand,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Fashion'd to Beatrice.

speaker: HERO
text_entry: And here's another

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Writ in my cousin's hand, stolen from her pocket,

speaker: HERO
text_entry: Containing her affection unto Benedick.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: A miracle! here's our own hands against our hearts.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Come, I will have thee; but, by this light, I take

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: thee for pity.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I would not deny you; but, by this good day, I yield

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: upon great persuasion; and partly to save your life,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: for I was told you were in a consumption.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Peace! I will stop your mouth.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Kissing her

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I'll tell thee what, prince; a college of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: wit-crackers cannot flout me out of my humour. Dost

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: thou think I  care for a satire or an epigram? No:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: if a man will be beaten with brains, a' shall wear

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: nothing handsome about him. In brief, since I do

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: purpose to marry, I will think nothing to any

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: purpose that the world can say against it; and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: therefore never flout at me for what I have said

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: against it; for man is a giddy thing, and this is my

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: conclusion. For thy part, Claudio, I did think to

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: have beaten thee, but in that thou art like to be my

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: kinsman, live unbruised and love my cousin.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: that I might have cudgelled thee out of thy single

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: life, to make thee a double-dealer; which, out of

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: question, thou wilt be, if my cousin do not look

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: exceedingly narrowly to thee.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Come, come, we are friends: let's have a dance ere

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and our wives' heels.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: We'll have dancing afterward.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: First, of my word; therefore play, music. Prince,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: thou art sad; get thee a wife, get thee a wife:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: there is no staff more reverend than one tipped with horn.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My lord, your brother John is ta'en in flight,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And brought with armed men back to Messina.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Think not on him till to-morrow:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I'll devise thee brave punishments for him.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Strike up, pipers.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Dance

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exeunt
